<description type="note">Preliminaries and editorial matter including introduction and glossary omitted.<lb/>The following plays have been taken from this source:<lb/>Source texts incomplete</description>
Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
XXXIV. THE SHERMEN. Christ led up to Calvary. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor
[PERSONS OF THE PLAY. Johannes. Maria. Jesus. Symon. Primus Miles. Secundus Miles. Wymond 3 Miles. Secunda Maria. Tertia Maria.]

[Scene I; The soldiers making ready for the crucifixion.] i Miles. Pees, barnes and bachillers Ã¾at beldis here aboute, Stirre no?t ones in Ã¾is stede but stonde stone stille, Or be Ã¾e lorde Ã¾at I leue on, I schall gar you lowte, But ?e spare when I speke youre speche schall I spille Smertely and sone; For I am sente fro sir Pilate with pride, To lede Ã¾is ladde oure lawes to abide, He gettis no bettir bone. Therfore I comaunde you on euere ilke a side, Vppon payne of enprisonment Ã¾at noman appere To suppowle Ã¾is traytoure, be tyme ne be tyde, Noght one of Ã¾is prees; Nor noght ones so hardy for to enquere, But helpe me holly, all that are here, Ãis kaitiffe care to encrees. 1. Therfore make rome and rewle you nowe right, That we may with Ã¾is weried wight Wightely wende on oure waye; He napped noght of all Ã¾is nyght, And Ã¾is daye schall his deth be dight, Latte see who dare saie naye. Be-cause to-morne is prouyde For oure dere Sabbott day, We wille no mysse be moued, But mirthe in all Ã¾at euere men may. 2. We haue bene besie all Ã¾is morne To clothe hym and to croune with thorne, As falles for a fole kyng; And nowe me thynkith oure felawes skorne, They highte to haue ben here Ã¾is morne, Ãis faitour forthe to bring: To nappe nowe is no?t goode, We! howe! high myght he hyng! ii Miles. Pees, man, for mahoundes bloode, Why make ?e such crying? 3. i Miles. Why wotte Ã¾ou noght als wele as I, Ãis carle burde vnto Caluery, And Ã¾ere on crosse be done? ii Miles. Sen dome is geuen Ã¾at he schall dy, Late calle to vs more companye, And ellis we erre oure fone. i Miles. Oure gere be-houes to be grayde, And felawes sammed sone, For Sir Pilate has saide Hym bus be dede be none. 4. Where is sir Wymond, wotte Ã¾ou oght? ii Miles. He wente to garre a crosse be wroght To bere Ã¾is cursed knave. i Miles. That wolde I sone wer hyder broght, For sithen schall othir gere be soght, That vs be-houes to haffe. ii Miles. Vs bus haue sties and ropes, To rugge hym tille he raue, And nayles and othir japes, If we oure selue wille saue. 5. i Miles. To tarie longe vs were full lathe, But Wymond come, it is in wathe But we be blamed all three. We! howe! Sir Wymond, wayt e[s] skathe. ii Miles. We, howe! Sir Wymond, howe? [Enter Wymond. iii Miles. I am here, what saie ?e bathe, Why crye ?e so on me? I haue bene garre make Ãis crosse, as yhe may see, Of Ã¾at laye ouere Ã¾e lake, Men called it Ã¾e kyngis tree. 6. i Miles. Nowe sekirly I Ã¾ought Ã¾e same, For Ã¾at balke will noman vs blame To cutte it for Ã¾e kyng. ii Miles. This karle has called hym kyng at hame, And sen Ã¾is tre has such a name, It is accordyng thyng, Ãat his rigge on it may reste, For skorne and for hethyng. iii Miles. Me thoughte it semyd beste Tille Ã¾is bargayne to bryng. 7. i Miles. It is wele warred, so motte I spede, And it be lele in lenghe and brede, Ã¾an is Ã¾is space wele spende. iii Miles. To loke Ã¾er-aftir it is no nede, I toke Ã¾e mesure or I yode, Bothe for Ã¾e fette and hande. ii Miles. Be-holde howe it is boorede Full euen at ilke an ende, This werke will wele accorde, It may not be amende. 8. iii Miles. Nay, I haue ordande mekill more, ?aa, thes theues are sente before, Ãat beside hym schall hang; And sties also are ordande Ã¾ore, With stalworthe steeles as mystir wore, Bothe some schorte and some lang. i Miles. For hameres and [for] nayles, Latte see sone who schall gang. ii Miles. Here are bragges Ã¾at will noght faile, Of irnne and stele full strange. 9. iii Miles. Ãanne is it as it aweth to bee, But whiche of yowe schall bere Ã¾is tree, Sen I haue broughte it hedir? i Miles. Be my feithe bere it schall hee Ãat Ã¾er-on hanged sone schall bee, And we schall teeche hym whedir. ii Miles. Vppon his bakke it schalle be laide, For sone we schall come thedir. iii Miles. Loke Ã¾at oure gere be grayede, And go we all to-gedir.

[Scene II; The road to Calvary: John, Mary, and others waiting.] 10. Johannes. Allas! for my maistir Ã¾at moste is of myght, That ?ister-even late, with lanternes light, Be-fore Ã¾e busshoppe was brought; Bothe Petir and I we saugh Ã¾at sight, And sithen we wente oure wayes full wight, When Ã¾e Jewes wondirly wrought. At morne Ã¾ei toke to rede, And soteltes vp soght, And demed hym to be dede Ãat to Ã¾am trespassed noght. 11. Allas! for syte, what schall I saie, My worldly welthe is wente for ay, In woo euere may I wende; My maistir, Ã¾at neuere lakke[d] in lay, Is demed to be dede Ã¾is day, Ewen in hys elmys hende. Allas! for my maistir mylde That all mennys mysse may mende, Shulde so falsely be filed, And no frendis hym to fende. 12. Allas! for his modir and oÃ¾ir moo, Mi modir and hir sisteres alsoo, Sittes samen with sighyngis sore; Ãai wate no-thyng of all Ã¾is woo, For-thy to warne Ã¾am will I goo, Sen I may mende no more. Sen he schall dye as tyte, And Ã¾ei vnwarned wore, I ware worthy to wite, I will go faste ther-fore. 13. But in myn herte grete drede haue I, Ãat his modir for dole schall dye, When she see ones Ã¾at sight; But certis I schal not wande for-thy, To warne Ã¾at carefull company, Or he to dede be dight A leaf, & vij, corresponding to & ij, is here lost. 14. [i Mary?] Sen he fro vs will twynne I schall Ã¾e neuere for-sake. Allas! Ã¾e tyme and tyde! I watte wele Ã¾e day is come Ãat are was specified, Of prophete Symeoun, in prophicie, The swerde of sorowe schulde renne Thurgh-oute Ã¾e herte, sotelly. 15. ii Maria. Allas! Ã¾is is a sithfull sight, He Ã¾at was euere luffely and light, And lorde of high and lawe; Oo! doulfully nowe is he dight, In worlde is none so wofull a wighte, Ne so carefull to knawe. Ãei Ã¾at he mended moste In dede and als in sawe, Now haue they full grete haste, To dede hym for to drawe. [Enter the soldiers, with Jesus bearing the cross. 16. Jesus. Doughteres of Jerusalem cytte, Sees, and mournes no more for me, But thynkes vppon this thyng; For youre selfe mourne schall ?ee, And for Ã¾e sonnes Ã¾at borne schal be Of yowe, bothe olde and yonge; For such fare schall be-falle, That ?e schall giffe blissyng To barayne bodies all, That no barnes forthe may brynge. 17. For certis ?e schall see suche a day, That with sore sighyng schall ?e saye Vnto Ã¾e hillis on highte, âFalle on vs, mountaynes, and ?e may, And couere vs fro Ã¾at felle affraye, affarye, That on vs sone schall light.â Turnes home Ã¾e toune vntill, Sen ?e haue Ã¾is sight, It is my fadirs will, Alle Ã¾at is done and dighte. 18. iii Maria. Allas! Ã¾is is a cursed cas, He Ã¾at alle hele in his hande has Shall here be sakles slayne; A! lorde, be leue lete clense thy face, Behalde howe he hath schewed his grace, Howe he is moste of mayne. This signe schalle bere witnesse Vnto all pepull playne, Howe goddes sone here gilteles Is putte to pereles payne. 19. i Miles. Saie, wherto bide ?e here aboute, Thare quenys, with Ã¾er skymeryng and Ã¾er schoute, Wille noght Ã¾er stevenis steere? ii Miles. Go home, casbalde with Ã¾i clowte, Or be Ã¾at lorde we loue and loute, Ãou schall a-bye full dere. iii Maria. This signe schall vengeaunce calle On yowe holly in feere. iii Miles. Go, hye Ã¾e hense with alle, Or ille hayle come Ã¾ou here. 20. Joh. Lady, youre gretyng greues me sore. Maria Sancta. John, helpe me nowe and neuere more. That I myght come hym tille. Joh. My lady, wende we forthe be-fore, To Caluery when ?e come thedir, Ãan schall ?e saie what ?e will. i Miles. What a deuyll is Ã¾is to saye, How longe schall we stande stille? Go hye you hens awaye, In Ã¾e deuylis name, doune Ã¾e hill. 21. ii Miles. Ther quenes vs comeres with Ã¾er clakke, He schall be serued for Ã¾er sake, With sorowe and with sore; iii Miles. And Ã¾ei come more such noyse to make, We schall garre lygge Ã¾ame in Ã¾e lake, Yf Ã¾ei were halfe a skore. [The women flee. i Miles. Latis nowe such bourdyng be, Sen oure tooles are before, Ãis traitoure and Ã¾is tree, Wolde I full fayne were Ã¾ore. 22. ii Miles. We schall no more so stille be stedde, For nowe Ã¾er quenes are fro vs fledde Ãat falsely wolde vs feere. iii Miles. Me thynkith Ã¾is boy is so for-bledde, With Ã¾is ladde may he noght be ledde, He swounes, Ã¾at dare I swere. i Miles. It nedis no?t harde to harle Sen it dose hym slike dere. ii Miles. I se here comes a karle, Shall helpe hym for to bere. [Enter Simon the Cyrenian. 23. iii Miles. Ãat schall ?e see sone one assaye. Goode man, whedir is Ã¾ou away? Ãou walkis as Ã¾ou were wrothe. Symon. Sir I haue a grete jornay, Ãat bus be done Ã¾is same day, Or ellis it may do skathe. i Miles. Ãou may with litill payne, Ease thy selffe and vs bathe. Symon. Goode sirs, Ã¾at wolde I fayne, But to dwelle were me lathe. 24. ii Miles. Nay, beuscher, Ã¾ou shall sone be spedde, Loo, here a ladde Ã¾at muste be ledde For his ille dedis to dye; iii Miles. And he is brosid and all for-bledde, That makis vs here Ã¾us stille be stedde, We pray Ã¾e, sir, for-thy, That Ã¾ou wilte take Ã¾is tree, And bere it to Caluerye. Symon. Goode sirs, Ã¾at may nou?t be, For full grete haste haue I. 25. My wayes are lang and wyde, And I may noght abide, For drede I come to late; For surete haue I hight Muste be fulfillid Ã¾is nyght, Or it will paire my state. Therfore, sirs, by youre leue, Me thynkith I dwelle full lang, Me were loth you for to greue, Goode sirs, ?e late me gang. 26. No lenger here now may I wone. i Miles. Nay, certis, Ã¾ou schalte no?t go so sone, For ought Ã¾at Ã¾ou can saye; Ãis dede is moste haste to be done, For Ã¾is boy muste be dede by none, And nowe is nere myddaye. Go helpe hym in Ã¾is nede, And make no more delaye. Symon. I praye yowe dose youre dede, And latis me wende my waye. 27. And, sirs, I schall come sone agayne, To helpe Ã¾is man with all my mayne, And even at youre awne will. ii Miles. What! wolde Ã¾ou trusse with such a trayne! Nay, faitour, Ã¾ou schalte be fayne, Ãis forwarde to full-fille. Or, be myghty mahounde! Ãou schalte rewe it full ille. iii Miles. Late dyng Ã¾is dastarde doune, But he goo tyte Ã¾er-till. 28. Symon. Sertis, sir, Ã¾at wer nought wisely wrought, To bete me, but I trespassid ought, Outhir in worde or dede. i Miles. Vppon his bakke it schall be brought, To bere it, whedir he wille or noght, What! deuyll, whome schulde we drede? Go, take it vppe be-lyve, And bere it forthe, goode spede! Symon. It helpis no?t here to striue, Bere it be-houes me nede. 29. And Ã¾erfore, sirs, as ?e haue saide, To bere Ã¾is crosse I holde me paied, Right as ?e wolde it wore. ii Miles. ?aa, nowe are we right arraied, Loke Ã¾at oure gere be redy grayed, To wirke whanne we come Ã¾ore. iii Miles. I warand all redy, Oure tooles bothe lesse and more, Late hym goo hardely, Forthe with Ã¾e crosse before. 30. i Miles. Sen he has his lade, nowe late hym gang, For with Ã¾is warlowe wirke we wrang, And we Ã¾us with hym yode. ii Miles. And nowe is noght goode to tarie lang, What schulde we done more vs emang? Say, sone, so motte Ã¾ou spede. iii Miles. Neuen vs no nodir noote, Tille we haue done Ã¾is dede. i Miles. We! me me-thynke we doote, He muste be naked, nede. 31. All yf he called hym-selffe a kyng, In his clothis he schall no?t hyng, But naked as a stone be stedde. ii Miles. That calle I accordand thyng, But tille his sidis I trowe Ã¾ei clyng, For bloode Ã¾at he has bledde. iii Miles. Wheder Ã¾ei clynge or cleue, Naked he schalle be ledde, And for Ã¾e more myscheue, Buffettis hym schall be bedde. 32. i Miles. Take of his clothis be-liffe, latte see, [They strip Jesus. A ha! Ã¾is garment will falle wele for mee, And so I hope it schall. ii Miles. Nay, sir, so may it noght be, Ãame muste be parte amonge vs thre, Take euen as will fall. iii Miles. ?aa, and sir Pilate medill hym, Youre parte woll be but small. i Miles. Sir, and ?e liste, go telle hym, ?itt schall he noght haue all, 33. Butte even his awne parte and nomore. ii Miles. ?aa, late Ã¾ame ligge still here in stoore, Vntill Ã¾is dede be done. iii Miles. Latte bynde hym as he was before, And harle on harde Ã¾at he wer Ã¾ore, And hanged or it be none. i Miles. He schall be feste of fee, And Ã¾at right sore and sone. ii Miles. So fallis hym for to be, He gettis no bettir bone. [They bind Jesus again. 34. iii Miles. Ãis werke is wele nowe, I warand, For he is boune as beeste in bande, That is demed for to dye. i Miles. Ãanne rede I Ã¾at we no lenger stande, But ilke man feste on hym a hande, And harle hym hense in hye. ii Miles. ?aa, nowe is tyme to trusse, To alle oure companye. iii Miles. If anye aske aftir vs, Kenne Ã¾ame to Caluarie.
